title: Markov switching multifractal
text:
In financial <a href="econometrics">econometrics</a> (the application of <a href="Statistics">statistical methods</a> to economic data), the Markov-switching multifractal (MSM) is a model of asset returns developed by <a href="Laurent-Emmanuel%20Calvet">Laurent E. Calvet</a> and Adlai J. Fisher that incorporates <a href="Stochastic%20Volatility">stochastic volatility</a> components of <a href="Homogeneity%20%28statistics%29">heterogeneous durations</a>. MSM captures the <a href="Outliers%20in%20statistics">outliers</a>, log-memory-like <a href="Volatility%20%28finance%29">volatility</a> persistence and power variation of <a href="financial%20return">financial return</a>s. In currency and equity series, MSM compares favorably with standard <a href="Stochastic%20volatility">volatility models</a> such as <a href="GARCH">GARCH(1,1)</a> and FIGARCH both in- and out-of-sample. MSM is used by practitioners in the financial industry to forecast <a href="Volatility%20%28finance%29">volatility</a>, compute <a href="Value%20at%20risk">value-at-risk</a>, and price <a href="Derivative%20%28finance%29">derivatives</a>.

MSM often provides better volatility forecasts than some of the best traditional models both in and out of sample. Calvet and Fisher report considerable gains in exchange rate volatility forecasts at horizons of 10 to 50 days as compared with GARCH(1,1), Markov-Switching GARCH, and Fractionally Integrated GARCH. Lux obtains similar results using linear predictions.
Applications.
Multiple assets and value-at-risk.
Extensions of MSM to multiple assets provide reliable estimates of the value-at-risk in a portfolio of securities.
Asset pricing.
In financial economics, MSM has been used to analyze the pricing implications of multifrequency risk. The models have had some success in explaining the excess volatility of stock returns compared to fundamentals and the negative skewness of equity returns. They have also been used to generate multifractal jump-diffusions.
Related approaches.
MSM is a stochastic volatility model with arbitrarily many frequencies. MSM builds on the convenience of regime-switching models, which were advanced in economics and finance by <a href="James%20D.%20Hamilton">James D. Hamilton</a>. 
MSM is closely related to the <a href="Multifractal%20Model%20of%20Asset%20Returns">Multifractal Model of Asset Returns</a>. MSM improves on the MMAR's combinatorial construction by randomizing arrival times, guaranteeing a strictly stationary process. 
MSM provides a pure regime-switching formulation of multifractal measures, which were pioneered by <a href="Beno%C3%AEt%20Mandelbrot">Benoit Mandelbrot</a>.
